children.value: This rule applies to any HTML
element or other element referenced by
is programmatically associated with an HTML element that has one of the listed form field
: The list of form field roles is derived by taking all the
role that itself inherits from one of those roles.
role is not part of the list of applicable roles, because it does not meet the definition of a
does not require it to have an accessible name.

: This rule is a partial check for WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.6, which applies to all labels. "Label" is used in its general sense and includes text or other components with a text alternative that is presented to a user to identify a component within Web content.
Each target element describes the purpose of the associated form field element.
: Labels do not need to be lengthy. A word, or even a single character, may suffice.
There are no major accessibility support issues known for this rule.
Understanding Success Criterion 2.4.6: Headings and Labels
H44: Using label elements to associate text labels with form controls
ARIA16: Using aria-labelledby to provide a name for user interface controls
Label that is coded with the
element and describes the purpose of the associated element.
<label for="fname">First name:</label> <input id="fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Label that is coded with the
element and associated by the aria-labelledby attribute. The label describes the purpose of the associated element.

<p id="label_fname">First name:</p>
<input aria-labelledby="label_fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Implicit label that is coded with the
element and describes the purpose of the associated element.
<label>First name:<input id="fname" type="text" name="fname"/></label>
Label is visible, but not included in accessibility tree

<p id="label_fname" aria-hidden="true">First name:</p>
<input aria-labelledby="label_fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Label is included in accessibility tree, but not visible

<p id="label_fname" style="position: absolute; top: -9999px; left: -9999px;">
	First name:
</p>
<input aria-labelledby="label_fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Label that is coded with the
element and does not describe the purpose of the associated element.
<label for="fname">Menu</label> <input id="fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Label that is coded with the
element and associated by the aria-labelledby attribute. The label does not describe the purpose of the associated element.

<p id="label_fname">Menu</p>
<input aria-labelledby="label_fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Implicit label that is coded with the
element and does not describe the purpose of the associated element.
<label>Menu<input id="fname" type="text" name="fname"/></label>
Label is visible, but not included in accessibility tree, and does not describe the purpose of the associated element.

<p id="label_fname" aria-hidden="true">Menu</p>
<input aria-labelledby="label_fname" type="text" name="fname" />
Label is included in accessibility tree, but not visible, and does not describe the purpose of the associated element.

<p id="label_fname" style="position: absolute; top: -9999px; left: -9999px;">
	Menu
</p>
<input aria-labelledby="label_fname" type="text" name="fname" />
that is neither visible to users, nor included in the accessibility tree.

<div style="display:none">
	<label for="bad_label">Menu:</label>
	<input id="fname" type="text" name="bad_label" />
</div>
element that is neither visible nor included in the accessibility tree.

<div style="display:none">
	<p id="bad_label">menu</p>
	<input aria-labelledby="bad_label" type="text" name="fname" />
</div>
element is associated with an HTML element that does not have a form field semantic role.

<label for="fname">First name</label>
<p id="fname">bob</p>
<i id="smile">Smile</i> <button aria-labelledby="smile">:-)</button>
<input id="fname" type="text" name="fname" />
